unicode.value: The Kingdoms of Life
LAURA MOYA RUIZ

CLIL enfocado al aprendizaje de los distintos reinos de los seres vivos en inglés. Desarrollo de habilidades comunicativas en inglés a través del estudio en dicho idioma, con distinto contenido audiovisual y ejercicios.

THE KINGDOMS OF LIFE

ARE ALL LIVING BEINGS THE SAME?

Visits

Didactic Unit for Year 5

by Laura Moya Ruiz
Justificación
Free Text
University of Auckland

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

Los idiomas son una herramienta que nos permite desarrollar nuestras ideas y pensamientos, así como poder expresarnos e intercambiar pensamientos con otros. Una de las mejores formas, por tanto, de aprender un idioma es utilizándolo, de acuerdo con el communicative approach. Con el fin de fomentar situaciones comunicativas, y el uso del inglés en el aula, se plantea la posibilidad de promover el aprendizaje de una materia en la nueva lengua, ya que para aprender un idioma no solo hay que saber de gramática y ortografía, sino que es fundamental el aspecto funcional y de uso, la fluidez, pronunciación, etc. que se desarrollan plenamente con el uso.

     Con el fin de desarrollar y mejorar las habilidiades comunicativas de nuestros alumnos en el cole, he desarrollado un proyecto CLIL basado en el estudio de la clasificación de los seres vivos y sus sus características, entre otros aspectos. Esta plataforma está enfocada para alumnos de 6º de primaria, para ser trabajada presencialmente en las sesiones de CLIL y, además, ser una herramienta de refuerzo y ampliación de conocimientos para los alumnos tanto dentro como fuera del aula.

     En este caso, y dada la complejidad del estudio de todos los reinos, en este CLIL se incluirán solamente 2 reinos: el reino animal y el reino de las plantas. La unidad incluye diferentes actividades para valorar diferentes aspectos, desde la comprensión lectora a la terminología específica.

     Topic: English - CLIL (natural science)

     Year: Year 6 (6º Primaria)    

     Author: Laura Moya Ruiz
University of Auckland
Objectives describe the expected outcomes of the learning and should define what the learners will be able to do when they have completed the learning tasks.
Type the learning objectives for this resource.

• Desarrollar y aplicar habilidades comunicativas en lengua inglesa mediante el aprendizaje de los seres vivos en dicho idioma.
  • Conocer los reinos en los que se clasifican los seres vivos.
  • Clasificar los animales de acuerdo con sus características.
  • Identificar las distintas familias dentro de las plantas.

THE KINGDOMS OF LIFE
Free Text
University of Auckland

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

Do you think all living beings are equal?

     What do you see in the pictures?

     In order to study living beings, researchers have classified and categorized them, from the smallest one to the biggest, depending on some characteristics. There have been stablished different classifications, according to new scientific discoveries and expert positions.

     Some of the aspects that are considered to classify living beings within one kingdom or another are the type of cell, how do they feed, how do they reproduce, etc. There are six kingdoms that scientists recognise at the moment, even though, there were others in the past. Each one of them has defining characteristics that help with the classification:   

  • ANIMALS
  • PLANTS
  • FUNGI
  • PROTOZOA
  • PROTISTA
  • BACTERIA
ANIMAL KINGDOM
Free Text
University of Auckland

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

The animal kingdom includes different organisms that are characterized by their capacity to move, their cells without cell wall nor chloroplasts, and their embryogenesis (how new life is created and developed). Human beings belong to this kingdom.

ANIMAL CLASSIFICATION

     Animals are living organisms which are heterotrophic and have motility. They are divided in two groups: vertebrates and invertebrates.

  • VERTEBRATES. Vertebrate animals are those who have vertebral column. Within this group, there are 5 families of animals: fish, birds, reptiles, amphibians and mammals. Each family has its own characteristics.
  • INVERTEBRATES. Invertebrates don't have internal skeleton, although some species have hard parts.
Free Text
University of Auckland

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

Some important characteristics of the Animal Kingdom are:

  • They are formed by more than one cell.
  • They feed on other beings through ingestion.
  • They breathe oxygen (most of them).
  • Animals have sexual reproduction.

Other classification

     Depending on their diet (what they eat), animals can be classified into:

  • Carnivorous. Those animals that eat other animals.
  • Herbivorous. Those animals that eat plants.
  • Omnivorous. Those animals who eat both animals and plants.
Free Text
University of Auckland

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

Vertebrate animals have internal skeleton. All of them have a backbone, which is a structure that surrounds and protects the spinal cord. The spinal cord connects all nerves in the body to the brain.

     Their body is divided into three different parts:

  • Head
  • Trunk
  • Extremities or legs.

     They are classified in 5 groups:

  • MAMMALS
  • BIRDS
  • FISH
  • REPTILES
  • AMPHIBIOUS

Mammals have the following characteristics:

  • All of them have internal bones and spine.
  • They have warm blood. They can regulate their body temperature to keep it constant (endothermic).
  • Most of them are born alive from their mothers, but marsupials, platypus and echidna, don't.
  • They breathe through lungs.
  • They can live in different places (water, air, ground).
  • They are the only family with animals covered by fur.

Reptiles have the following characteristics:

  • Reptiles cannot regulate and keep their body temperature, so they get their body heat from external sources. They are cold-blooded (exothermic).
  • They are the longest lived species on the planet. Tortoises can live more than 150 years.
  • Their bodies are covered with scales, or they have bony external plate (shell)
  • Reptiles cannot chew their food, they can only tear
  • Most reptiles lay eggs, although some lizards are viviparous.
  • Some of them are terrestrial, others live in water.

Birds have the following characteristics:

  • Birds can regulate their body temperature. They are called warm-blooded (endothermic).
  • They don't have teeth, and they present toothless bills/beaks.
  • Birds are born from eggs.
  • All their body is covered with feathers, being the only animals, which have them.
  • Some birds' skeleton is composed of porous lightweight bones (to help them fly).
  • Birds can fly using wings, and live most of their lives in the air.

Amphibians have the following characteristics:

  • Thin and humid skin, without fur, scales or feathers. Their skin is prepared to protect the animal. Their skin protects, controls their corporal temperature and it helps breathing. It can also produce toxic substances that persuades enemies.
  • Amphibians transform themselves in their growth, passing from living in the water, to living outside it. They breathe through gills (they live in the water), through lungs (they live both in humid areas and on the ground), and through their skin.
  • They reproduce through eggs.
  • They can't control their body temperature, which is called cold-blooded (exothermic).

Free Text

Fish have the following characteristics:

  • They generally live all their life underwater, although some fish can live out of it (mudskippers).
  • Fish have gills throughout its life cycle to breath.
  • Many fish have scales covering all their bodies. There are many types of scales, and they shield the body from the environment. They also improve their movements in the water.
  • Fins are anatomic parts of fish. Their general purpose is to provide motion and maneuverability.
  • Almost all fish are cold-blooded animals, as they cannot regulate their body temperature (exothermic).

Free Text

Invertebrates don't have internal skeleton: inside them there are no bones, and they don't have backbone. They have soft inner bodies which are held in shape by a flexible covering of outer cells.

     However, some invertebrate species have got some hard parts, such as shells or conches, to protect them. Others have a rigid covering called exoskeleton. Finally, some of them have got a soft body without protection.
Investigation project

string.value: CSS class

unicode.value: The title and the icon are not required. If you leave them empty the iDevice will have no emphasis.

Time
45:00
Grouping
Individual

     You have seen different types of invertebrate animals. Now, choose one type of invertebrate and create your own conceptual map. If you need so, you can investigate about your choice, use your own pictures, etc.

     The steps you can follow are:

  1. Choose one type of invertebrates.
  2. Get the information about it.
  3. Use Freeplane to create your own map.
Non-Interactive Activities

University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

INVERTEBRATES

     Invertebrates don't have internal skeleton : inside them there are no bones, and they don't have backbone . They have soft inner bodies which are held in shape by a flexible covering of outer cells.

     However, some invertebrate species have got some hard parts , such as shells or conches, to protect them. Others have a rigid covering called exoskeleton . Finally, some of them have got a soft body without protection.
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

Enter the text for the cloze activity in to the cloze field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

INVERTEBRATES

     Invertebrates don't have internal skeleton : inside them there are no bones, and they don't have backbone . They have soft inner bodies which are held in shape by a flexible covering of outer cells.

     However, some invertebrate species have got some hard parts , such as shells or conches, to protect them. Others have a rigid covering called exoskeleton . Finally, some of them have got a soft body without protection.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.

Internal skeleton: bone structure that is inside animals.

Backbone: spine. Chain of bones that vertebrates have in the back.

Exoskeleton: external skeleton that supports and protects the animal's body.

True/false questions present a statement where the learner must decide if the statement is true. This type of question works well for factual information and information that lends itself to either/or responses.
Type the question stem. The question should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.

Multiple choice
University of Auckland

Although more often used in formal testing situations MCQs can be used as a testing tool to stimulate thought and discussion on topics students may feel a little reticent in responding to. When designing a MCQ test consider the following:
  • What learning outcomes are the questions testing
  • What intellectual skills are being tested
  • What are the language skills of the audience
  • Gender and cultural issues
  • Avoid grammar language and question structures that might provide clues

When building an MCQ consider the following:
  • Use phrases that learners are familiar with and have encountered in their study
  • Keep responses concise
  • There should be some consistency between the stem and the responses
  • Provide enough options to challenge learners to think about their response
  • Try to make sure that correct responses are not more detailed than the distractors
  • Distractors should be incorrect but plausible
Introduzca la pregunta. La pregunta debe ser clara y no ambigua. Evite las premisas negativas ya que estas tienden a confundir a los estudiantes.

Plants are autotrophic organisms, it is to say, they can make their own food by means of a process called photosynthesis. The photosynthesis process takes place inside the leaves. Plants produce sap, which is the food of plants.

     To produce sap, plants need three basic components:

  • Water and mineral salts that they take from the floor.
  • Carbon dioxide that is taken from the air by the leaves.
  • Energy that is obtained from the Sun.
Reproduction in plants
Free Text
University of Auckland

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

There are two types of reproduction:

  • Sexual reproduction
  • Asexual reproduction

ASEXUAL REPRODUCTION

     Asexual plants are capable of create a new plant without needing sexual cells, even when they have flowers. Asexual reproduction systems are:

  • Spores reproduction. They are cells that can form a new plant when they fall to the ground.
  • Bulb, tubers, rhizomes, stolons and slips.

 

SEXUAL REPRODUCTION

     Plants' sexual reproduction takes place through flowers, which are where the reproductive organs of this plants are. Sexual reproduction involves two types of cells: female and male. From the union of them, a new plant comes out.
Free Text
University of Auckland

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

Plants are more difficult to put into groups than animals. Because of that, people usually know two main groups, instead of four. They are:

  • Moss
  • Fern
  • Plants with flowers
  • Plants without flowers
Moss and Fern
Free Text
University of Auckland

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

Both ferns and moss are plants without flowers. Because of it, they don't reproduce by fruits and seeds, but by spores. Spores are special cells which are surrounded with a resistant cover. They are the origin of new plants when they arrive to a different place, as they are spread by the wind and water.

Plants with flowers
Free Text
University of Auckland

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

Plants are divided in two groups: plants with flowers (angiosperms) and plants without flowers.

     Flowering plants are those with complex flashy flowers. Their seeds are covered with fruits that protect them. Plants from this group have the following characteristics:

  • They have flowers. They can be big or small.
  • They have fruits. Inside them there are seeds, which have the genetic information for a new plant, and the nutrients it needs to grow.
  • They can be herbs, trees or bushes.
Plants without flowers
Free Text
University of Auckland

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

Plants are divided in two groups: plants with flowers and plants without flowers.

     Plants without flowers are those that don't produce flowers, including moss, ferns, horse's tail, pines, firs or cypresses. They can be classified in three groups: moss, ferns and plants without flowers (gymnosperms).

     This last group, plants without flowers, have the following characteristics:

  • They have small and simple flowers.
  • They have no fruits.
  • Seeds usually are formed inside pines.
  • They are evergreen trees and bushes.
  • They have needle-shaped or scaled leaves.

unicode.value: Write the name of each part of the flower.
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

1. Corolla
  2. Pistil
  3. Stamen
  4. Petal
  5. Ovary
  6. Calyx
  7. Sepal
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

Enter the text for the cloze activity in to the cloze field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

1. Corolla
  2. Pistil
  3. Stamen
  4. Petal
  5. Ovary
  6. Calyx
  7. Sepal

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.
Reading activity. INVESTIGATION
University of Auckland

The Reading Activity will primarily be used to check a learner's comprehension of a given text. This can be done by asking the learner to reflect on the reading and respond to questions about the reading, or by having them complete some other possibly more physical task based on the reading.

Teachers should keep the following in mind when using this iDevice:

  1. Think about the number of different types of activity planned for your resource that will be visually signalled in the content. Avoid using too many different types or classification of activities otherwise learner may become confused. Usually three or four different types are more than adequate for a teaching resource.
  2. From a visual design perspective, avoid having two iDevices immediately following each other without any text in between. If this is required, rather collapse two questions or events into one iDevice.
  3. Think about activities where the perceived benefit of doing the activity outweighs the time and effort it will take to complete the activity.
Enter the details of the reading including reference details. The referencing style used will depend on the preference of your faculty or department.
What to read
The website below is full of information about plants. Read the following questions and look for the information to answer them.
Describe the tasks related to the reading learners should undertake. This helps demonstrate relevance for learners.

• What are decidious trees?
  • Find some plant defences.
  • How are seeds spread?
Use feedback to provide a summary of the points covered in the reading, or as a starting point for further analysis of the reading by posing a question or providing a statement to begin a debate.

The external website iDevice loads an external website into an inline frame in your eXe content rather then opening it in a popup box. This means learners are not having to juggle windows. This iDevice should only be used if your content will be viewed by learners online.

True/false questions present a statement where the learner must decide if the statement is true. This type of question works well for factual information and information that lends itself to either/or responses.
Type the question stem. The question should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.

FINAL ACTIVITIES
Compare and contrast
University of Auckland
Provide relevant feedback on the situation.

A case study is a device that provides learners with a simulation that has an educational basis. It takes a situation, generally based in reality, and asks learners to demonstrate or describe what action they would take to complete a task or resolve a situation. The case study allows learners apply their own knowledge and experience to completing the tasks assigned. when designing a case study consider the following:
  • What educational points are conveyed in the story
  • What preparation will the learners need to do prior to working on the case study
  • Where the case study fits into the rest of the course
  • How the learners will interact with the materials and each other e.g. if run in a classroom situation can teams be setup to work on different aspects of the case and if so how are ideas feed back to the class
Describe the activity tasks relevant to the case story provided. These could be in the form of questions or instructions for activity which may lead the learner to resolving a dilemma presented.

Create the case story. A good case is one that describes a controversy or sets the scene by describing the characters involved and the situation. It should also allow for some action to be taken in order to gain resolution of the situation.

Anylize the information about the Animal Kingdom and Plant Kingdom. Using thtat information, create a Venn Diagram to compare and contrast both kingdoms.

     Create your Venn Diagram using GOOGLE DRAW.

Look, think and say
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
University of Auckland

Reflection is a teaching method often used to connect theory to practice. Reflection tasks often provide learners with an opportunity to observe and reflect on their observations before presenting these as a piece of academic work. Journals, diaries, profiles and portfolios are useful tools for collecting observation data. Rubrics and guides can be effective feedback tools.
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Reflective question:

Look at the images. Analyze each picture and write down their characteristics. Then classify those living being according to those characteristicss.

Write your results and expose your classification of one of them to the rest of the class.
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
You can use visual support to expose your results, such a conceptual map or a presentation with edPuzzle.
